skill.name: browser-use
skill.description: Automates browser interactions for web testing, form filling, screenshots, and data extraction. Use when the user needs to navigate websites, interact with web pages, fill forms, take screenshots, or extract information from web pages.
skill.summary: Browser automation CLI for web testing, form filling, screenshots, and data extraction
skill.author: browser-use

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged patterns in SKILL.md documentation as potential security risks. After evaluation, all findings are false positives: bash code blocks were misidentified as shell execution, example URLs were flagged as hardcoded network endpoints, and documented environment variables were misclassified as credential access. The skill is a legitimate browser automation CLI tool with no malicious code or behavior patterns.

medium_findings.title: Documentation Code Blocks Misidentified as Shell Execution
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged 67 instances of 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' in SKILL.md markdown file. These are bash code block examples (```bash ... ```) used for documentation purposes, not actual backtick shell execution.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Clear evidence: markdown code fences in documentation file are syntactic examples, not code execution. No shebangs or actual shell scripts present.

medium_findings.title: Example URLs in Documentation Misidentified as Hardcoded Network Endpoints
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged 6 hardcoded URLs in SKILL.md. These are example URLs (https://example.com, https://gmail.com, etc.) used in documentation to demonstrate CLI usage.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: These are legitimate example URLs in documentation, clearly labeled as examples. No network requests to these URLs occur in the code.

medium_findings.title: Documented Environment Variables Misclassified as Credential Access
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged environment variable references (BROWSER_USE_API_KEY, OPENAI_API_KEY, ANTHROPIC_API_KEY) as credential access. These are documented configuration options for the CLI tool.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Documentation of legitimate environment variable configuration for API authentication. No evidence of credential exfiltration or unauthorized access.

low_findings.title: Base64 Encoding Reference in Screenshot Output
low_findings.description: Documentation mentions base64 output for screenshots. Base64 is encoding, not cryptographic encryption.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Base64 encoding is standard for image data transfer. Not a security concern.

content.user_title: Automate browser interactions for web tasks
content.value_statement: Automates complex browser workflows including form filling, data extraction, and multi-step web testing scenarios. Enables persistent browser sessions with Python scripting for advanced automation.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to URLs and manage browser sessions across commands
Interact with web page elements using index-based selection
Take screenshots and save them to files
Execute Python scripts with persistent browser object access
Run AI agent tasks to autonomously complete complex browser workflows
Manage multiple browser sessions in parallel
limitations: Agent tasks require an API key for LLM access
Cloud browser mode requires remote API configuration
Cannot interact with browser extensions or plugins
Real browser mode requires Chrome to be installed

use_cases.title: Automated Form Testing and Data Entry
use_cases.description: Fill out web forms programmatically for testing workflows or data entry tasks. Navigate to pages, identify form elements by index, input text, and submit forms automatically.
use_cases.target_user: QA engineers and developers testing web forms

use_cases.title: Web Data Extraction and Screenshots
use_cases.description: Extract structured data from web pages using Python scripts or AI-powered extraction. Capture full-page screenshots for documentation or visual regression testing.
use_cases.target_user: Data engineers and researchers collecting web data

use_cases.title: Multi-Step Browser Workflow Automation
use_cases.description: Create persistent browser sessions that maintain state across commands. Use Python scripting to coordinate complex multi-step workflows like login sequences, checkout flows, or data processing pipelines.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Browser Navigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use browser-use to navigate to https://example.com and tell me what elements are available on the page.

prompt_templates.title: Form Filling
prompt_templates.prompt: Use browser-use to fill out the contact form at https://example.com/contact with the following data: Name: John Doe, Email: john@example.com, Message: Testing. Then submit the form and verify the result.

prompt_templates.title: Screenshot Capture
prompt_templates.prompt: Use browser-use to take a full-page screenshot of https://example.com and save it to /tmp/screenshot.png. Then extract any text visible on the page using Python.

prompt_templates.title: Complex Multi-Step Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Use browser-use with the agent capability to: 1) Login to https://example.com/login with credentials, 2) Navigate to the dashboard, 3) Extract all visible data tables, 4) Take screenshots of each section. Use --max-steps 50 for the agent.

best_practices: Always run 'browser-use state' first to see available elements and their indices before interacting
Use '--headed' mode when debugging to observe browser behavior visually
Close browsers with 'browser-use close' when done to free system resources
anti_patterns: Do not leave browsers running between sessions without tracking session names
Avoid using 'real' browser mode for untrusted websites as it uses your actual browser profile
Do not skip element inspection with 'state' before clicking or typing

faq.question: What is the difference between chromium, real, and remote browser modes?
faq.answer: Chromium mode uses an isolated headless Chrome instance. Real mode uses your existing Chrome profile with cookies and extensions. Remote mode connects to a cloud browser service requiring API configuration.

faq.question: How do I run multiple browsers in parallel?
faq.answer: Use the --session flag to create named sessions. Each session maintains its own browser instance. Commands without --session use the 'default' session.

faq.question: What Python variables persist across commands?
faq.answer: Variables defined with 'browser-use python' persist within the same session. The 'browser' object provides access to browser state and methods. Use --reset to clear the namespace.

faq.question: Do I need an API key to use browser-use?
faq.answer: Basic navigation and interaction commands work without an API key. Agent tasks and AI-powered extraction require an API key configured via BROWSER_USE_API_KEY or other supported LLM keys.

faq.question: How do I stop a stuck browser server?
faq.answer: Run 'browser-use server stop' to stop any stuck server. Use 'browser-use close --all' to terminate all browser sessions.

faq.question: Can I use browser-use for web scraping?
faq.answer: Yes. Use Python scripts with browser navigation and data extraction, or leverage the AI agent for complex extraction tasks. For high-volume scraping, consider rate limiting and respect website terms of service.
